Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

currentDoc:
Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure.

I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.

I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget.

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover.

So I favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.

An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audio

currentDoc:
Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook.

S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover.

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it.

You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading an a

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook.

You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is l

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting anot

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audi

You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them vi

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget.

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. The

I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very differ

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

currentDoc:
Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things!

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things!

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook.

I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my fi

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true lov

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget.

And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is a

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can ho

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and st

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook.

  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain

currentDoc:
Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is worth more than any convenience I might ever get from listening to a book.

 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is worth more than any convenience I might ever get from listening to a book.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands, feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.

And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is worth more than any convenience I might ever get from listening to a book.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands,feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library or an antiquarian store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook.

And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is worth more than any convenience I might ever get from listening to a book.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?

---

In my opinion, nothing compares with a real book. I have no argument with audiobooks, but when it comes to pure enjoyment and pleasure, nothing beats a real book in my hands; feeling the paper, the weight, turning the pages, smelling and feeling the book jacket, seeing my neat handwriting on the inside page of the front cover. 

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library, antique store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An antique, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is worth more than any convenience I might ever get from listening to a book.

I love to get an interesting or unusual book from a library, antique store or a friend, and then get to know the book and its quirks and treasures. An historic, leather-bound book is a delight, the ultimate sensory pleasure. The smell of an old leather-bound book is a metaphor for the wisdom and beauty locked inside.

n audiobook is not quite the same experience.
  Screens and electronics are everywhere, and the last thing I want to do after a day of working on the computer is go to bed with a gadget. 
S favor real books that I can hold in my hands, and turn the pages lovingly.
 The book itself is part of the experience, and I feel cheated when I listen to an audio-book. I feel almost as if someone might "steal the soul" out of the book for me, if I had to listen to it as an audiobook. 

You miss out on a lot when you listen rather than go through the book yourself. Some of it is simply the physical experience. You don't enjoy the book in the same way, and you don't form the same attachments. You don't write in it, you don't look at the photos or illustrations in it. And I wonder how much of the story is lost because it is read to you, rather than read by yourself.

Reading a book is like meeting another person face-to-face.  Audiobooks are like meeting them via social media or a dating app. They are very different things! And there's nothing wrong with either one, but neither can take the place of the other. For me, my true love is a book I can hold. The ownership and stimulation I gain is worth more than any convenience I might ever get from listening to a book.

Is Listening to a Book Just as Good as Reading It?

Do you listen to audiobooks? What are the benefits, in your opinion, of listening instead of reading? Are there advantages to reading that cannot be gained by listening? Which method do you prefer? Why?
